intro: Chondrilla hookeriana, commonly known as Hooker's chondrilla, is a perennial flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky and arid environments, demonstrating a high degree of adaptability to harsh conditions. Its leaves are usually gray-green and covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Chondrilla hookeriana is also noted for its small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer, adding a subtle ornamental value to its natural habitat.
